name: building construction, hostel | building, hostel | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19626/documentation

This dataset represents construction of a tourist accommodation facility classed as a hostel, located in Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.  It was first opened in 2016 although the building where the hostel resides was constructed in 1959. Prior to becoming a hostel, the building was used as residence. The hostel has capacity of 30 and offers rooms of the following types (total number of rooms is given in brackets): double (2) and shared use (3). The hostel has 3 floors with a games room in the underground, a lobby and a pool on the ground floor, and the rooms and kitchen in the first floor. This hostel does not serve breakfast. The laundry is done in the hostel dependecies and there is no parking available on site. The hostel occupies a total area of 365,49 m2 where the building itself occupies the plot of 172,65 m2. The average annual occupancy of the hostel is 58% which is equal to 6300 guest nights per year. The load bearing structure of hotel building is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork.

This dataset is modelled to include the inputs for the construction of a hostel building. This includes: energy and water used in construction, land transformation, building structure and outer building shell, foundations, inner walls, roofs, ceiling and windows, doors, floors, finishing and painting, bathroom equipment. Activities include hotel building construction with lifeframe of the hotel building of 75 years. Maintenance is included only through the consideration of the lifetime of the different exchanges. For example, windows are assumed to have a lifetime of 35 years, therefore the exchange amount is multiplied by 75years / 35 years=2.14. 

Activities end with 1 unit of hostel building, including maintenance. Due to data availability, the following building construction processes have been excluded: cables, gutter, drains, ventilation.
category: F:Construction/41:Construction of buildings/410:Construction of buildings/4100:Construction of buildings

processDocumentation.timeDescription: The survey was done in the year 2017 with the data provided covering the operational year 2016-2017.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: The hostel is based in the city of Rio de Janeiro, RJ, Brazil.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The level of technology is considered current. The load bearing structure of hotel building is made of concrete and the facade is made of concrete and brickwork.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: In terms of construction, the amounts of input material are calculated based on usage across all instances within the hotel building.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Primary data from the hotel supplemented with literature-based calculations and estimates, where appropriate.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Assuming that 1.39 kWh/m3 of diesel is necessary to construct a building. Source: Zabalza et al. 2013. Use of LCA as a Tool for Building Ecodesign. A Case Study of a Low Energy Building in Spain. Energies, 6(8), 3901-3921. Assuming 1 kWh = 3.6 MJ

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel / lifetime of the product). Used here in place of water soluble acrylic paint and alkyd enamel. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls. Assuming 1 liter of paint is required to paint 10m2 and weighs 1.5 kg. Source:  BQ 2018. Wall painting calculator. Available from: https://www.diy.com/help-advice/wall-painting-calculator/Dev_npcart_100008.art Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of 5 years which is equivalent to the period of major refurbishments in hotels. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19(17-18), 1917-1930. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste paint on wall.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. 

Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls (15.128m3). Assumed thickness of 225 mm, http://kingspaninsulation.co.uk/getattachment/5fdd04b2-e58e-4622-97bb-5861799ab02a/Thermafloor-TF70-pdf.pdf.  Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout.

Additionally the concrete for foundations is accounted for (17.265m3). Calculated value. Combined of all instances of use across the building structure and walls. Assumed thickness of 225 mm, http://kingspaninsulation.co.uk/getattachment/5fdd04b2-e58e-4622-97bb-5861799ab02a/Thermafloor-TF70-pdf.pdf.  Assumed service life of 75 years which is equal to the service life of the hotel building with minor refurbishments throughout.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hostel / lifetime of the product). Combined of all instances of use across the building floor and roof. Assuming that 73.8kg/m2 of tiles required of roof ceramic tiles, https://www.marleyeternit.co.uk/~/media/Roofing-Specification/pdfs/Roofing-Specification-Guide---Concrete.pdf. Assumed service life of 75 years with minor refurbishments throughout. Assuming 12.3 kg of tiles is required to cover 1 m2 of floor area. Source:  Victoria Plumbing 2018. British ceramic tile. Available from: https://victoriaplum.com/product/british-ceramic-tile-metro-bevel-white-gloss-tile-100mm-x-200mm Accessed 16 March 2018. Assumed service life of 5 years for floor ceramic tile which is equivalent to the period of major refurbishments in hotels. Source: Filimonau et al. 2011. Reviewing the carbon footprint analysis of hotels: Life Cycle Energy Analysis (LCEA) as a holistic method for carbon impact appraisal of tourist accommodation. Journal of Cleaner Production, 19(17-18), 1917-1930. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to insert waste.

Source: ASHRAE 2018. ASHRAE Equipment Life Expectancy chart. Available from: http://www.culluminc.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/02/ASHRAE_Chart_HVAC_Life_Expectancy%201.pdf Accessed 23 March 2018.

exchanges.description:
Calculated value. Assuming that 0.5 kl per 1 m2 of floor area (AFA) is required in building construction. Source: Crawford et al. 2005. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to wastewater. Value double checked in McCormack, et al. 2007.

Reference:

Crawford, Robert and Treloar, Graham 2005, An assessment of the energy and water embodied in commercial building construction, in Australian Life Cycle Assessment Conference (4th : 2005 : Novotel, Sydney, N.S.W.), Australian Life Cycle Assessment Society, Sydney, N.S.W., pp. 1-10. 

McCormack, et al. 2007. Modelling direct and indirect water requirements of construction. Building research & information. 35(2), 156-162.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. Combined of all instances of all across the building walls (data in m3) and roof (data in m2). Assumed thickness of roof plasterboard 12.5 mm. Source: Practical DYI 2018. Types of plasterboard. Available from: https://www.practicaldiy.com/general-building/plasterboard/plasterboard.php Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed density of plasterboard 640 kg/m3. Source: British Gypsum 2018. What is the density of Gyproc plasterboards? Available from: http://www.british-gypsum.com/technical-advice/faqs/114-what-is-the-density-of-gyproc-plasterboards Accessed 23 March 2018. Assumed service life of 75 years with minor refurbishments throughout. In terms of outputs assumed to have gone to waste gypsum plasterboard.

exchanges.description: Calculated value. The amount of exchange is calculated as: amount of input product * (lifetime of the hotel / lifetime of the product). This flow represents ceramic washing basin and ceramic toilet seat. The hostel has 7 washing basins and 5 toilet seats. Washing basins are assumed to weigh 15kg (information taken from IKEA (2018) for the product "TÖRNVIKEN Countertop wash-basin", source retrieved from: http://www.ikea.com/gb/en/products/washstands-taps/wash-basins/t%C3%B6rnviken-countertop-wash-basin-white-art-90291518/, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. Toilet seats are assumed to weigh 35kg (information taken from B&Q (2018) for the product "COOKE & LEWIS FABIENNE CLOSE-COUPLED TOILET WITH SOFT CLOSE SEAT", source retrieved from: https://www.diy.com/departments/cooke-lewis-fabienne-close-coupled-toilet-with-soft-close-seat/1142804_BQ.prd?B/R_Toilets_C_CT, accessed 12 Feb 2018). The assumed lifetime is 15 years. In terms of outputs, assumed to have gone to inert waste.
